Rationale: Primary research focus: oral microbiome alterations in AD. Central to oral-brain axis hypothesis.
Primary research focus: gut microbiome alterations in AD. Central to gut-brain axis hypothesis.
Unique aspect of this study: paired oral-gut analysis in AD. Minimal taxonomic overlap finding.
Theoretical framework: oral microbiome directly affects brain. Alternative to gut-brain axis.
Established paradigm: gut microbiome affects brain. Compare with oral-brain axis findings.
Mechanism: oral bacteria translocate to gut. Contradicts our minimal overlap finding.
Oral bacteria reach brain via bloodstream. Supports oral-brain axis.
Key oral pathogen linked to AD. Periodontal disease connection.

Top protective species in our study (-2.9 FC). Beneficial oral bacteria.
Dominant species in Meta-Topic_7 (51.91%). Beneficial community marker.
Our sequencing technology: WGS metagenomics with MetaPhlAn 4 profiling.
Our community detection method: LDA topic modeling for microbiome communities.
Community-level analysis approach. Multi-seed LDA framework.
Our novel approach: multiple random seeds for robust community detection.
CLR transformation and compositional data handling. Our statistical approach.
Our primary statistical model: GLMM for repeated measures.
Critical confounder in our study. Clinical Frailty Scale association.
Critical confounder: 60% AD vs 26% controls. Medication-microbiome interactions.
3.2-fold higher in AD (40% vs 12.5%). Known microbiome effects.
Proton pump inhibitors affect gut microbiome. Potential confounder.
MNA score significantly different. Nutrition-microbiome interactions.

Oral health and cognitive function. Supporting evidence.
